frqParts.text: Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A projectile is launched from the back of a cart of mass <math alttext="m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> that is held at rest, as shown above. At time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> , the projectile leaves the cart with speed <math alttext="v sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> at an angle <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> above the horizontal. The projectile lands at point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Assume that the starting height of the projectile above the ground is negligible compared to the maximum height reached by the projectile and the horizontal distance traveled. (a) Derive an expression for the time <math alttext="t sub P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> at which the projectile reaches point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="v sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

(b) On the axes below, sketch the horizontal component <math alttext="v sub x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and the vertical component <math alttext="v sub y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> of the velocity of the projectile as a function of time <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> from <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> until <math alttext="t equals t sub P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Explicitly label the vertical intercepts with algebraic expressions.

The projectile is again launched from the same position, but with the cart traveling to the right with speed <math alttext="v sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> relative to the ground, as shown above. The projectile again leaves the cart with speed <math alttext="v sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> relative to the cart at an angle <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> above the horizontal, and the projectile lands at point <math alttext="Q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Q</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, which is a horizontal distance <math alttext="D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> from the launching point. Express your answers in terms of <math alttext="v sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate. (c) Give a physical reason why the projectile lands at point <math alttext="Q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Q</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, which is not as far from the launch position as point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is, and explain how that physical reason affects the flight of the projectile.

(d) Derive an expression for <math alttext="v sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="v sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

After the launch, the cart’s speed is <math alttext="v sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Beginning at time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, the cart experiences a braking force of <math alttext="F equals negative b v" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>b</mi></mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="b" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is a positive constant with units of <math alttext="kilograms per second" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>kg</mtext><mo>/</mo><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mrow></math> and <math alttext="v" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the speed of the cart. Express your answers to the following in terms of <math alttext="m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="b" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="v sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate. (e) i. Using Newton’s second law, write but DO NOT solve a differential equation that represents the motion of the cart while it experiences the braking force.

ii. Show that the speed <math alttext="v of t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> of the cart as a function of time is given by the equation <math alttext="v of t equals v sub 2, end subscript, times e raised to the negative b t, over m, power" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>b</mi></mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mo>/</mo><mi>m</mi></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>.

iii. Derive an expression for the distance the cart travels from <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> until the time it comes to a stop.
